pullRequest.body:
This file introduces the `BinomialRing` mixin (for semirings) and the `Ring.multichoose` function, which generalizes `Nat.multichoose`.  These are preliminaries to introducing generalized binomial coefficients.

---


[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Hi, and thanks for your first PR! Could you please change the title of your PR to something more informative and following our [commit conventions](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/commit.html). For example `feat: define binomial rings` would be perfectly fine. Also, the "assigning" mechanism is made for reviewers and maintainers to assign themselves/someone else as responsible for the review process of that PR, so there's no point in assigning yourself to your own PR.

Unfortunately @jjaassoonn accidentally merged his branch into yours in #3878 after [bors changed the base branch](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/bors.20changed.20base.20branch). You'd need to force push when you push the next time, or alternatively you may pull in the last commit and revert it.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7433154681/job/20225821774)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7433154681/job/20225821372)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7433154681/job/20225821685)

Thanks!

maintainer merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Thanks for your PR! I left a few comments.

Thanks!

maintainer merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Can you put spaces around colons and plus signs?
I think I fixed all of them.
Maybe surround this and the following theorems with a section that has `variable [Semiring R]`?
Thank you, that is a great idea.
Isn't this equivalent to the ring being torsion free?

The equivalence is true for rings, and I had thought it also held for semirings until quite recently.  A counterexample is given by taking the free \N-algebra on generators x and y, and quotienting by the relation 2x = 2y.
Ah, but at least it's equivalent to multiplication by integers being injective?
Yes, for strictly positive integers.  Also equivalent: the map $$R \to R \otimes_{\mathbb{N}} \mathbb{Q}_{\geq 0}$$ given by $$r \mapsto r \otimes 1$$ is injective.

Are you suggesting that I change the first condition to something like `inj_pos_int : âˆ€ (n : â„•) (r s : R), n â‰  0 â†’ n * r = n * s â†’ r = s` ?  I think such a change would be relatively painless, so if you think that is more natural, I am happy to do so.
Yes, that does feel more natural to me.

We've generalized [IsDomain](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Ring/Defs.html#IsDomain) to use a cancellative condition (@riccardobrasca in [#17831](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/17831)); should we generalize [NoZeroSMulDivisors](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Basic.html#NoZeroSMulDivisors) too?
I have changed the first condition following your suggestion.
@alreadydone Perhaps a different name would be more appropriate.  For example, `NonzeroSmulInjective`.
I feel like this might be better phrased in terms of `pochEval r n` being divisible by `n.factorial`.
I have rewritten the docstrings to better reflect this.
No, I mean you could change the actual lean code to be in terms of divisibility, and then you wouldn't have to have multichoose be part of the data, since it would be uniquely determined.

I see.  That was the original method I used, but a Zulip conversation convinced me to try it this way: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/How.20prove.20things.20about.20Exists.2Echoose.20terms.3F

We actually have a nice references system and a bibfile (e.g https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/27866b848920f9620ed5a72c9039fff58e479d6f/Mathlib/NumberTheory/FunctionField.lean#L34) can you format this using that instead?

(Ok it doesn't actually work yet with the new doc-gen but it should at some point in the future I assume and at that point it will be good if this is formatted properly)
Yes, I think the new revision is in the right format.
Please either use tex and put this (and other pseudo code mixed into comments) in double dollar signs or use backticks ` and lean-ish code
Thank you, I think I got all of them.
I would simply leave this out for now
Done!

It looks like this is a general statement about `Commute` so it should be moved to a more general place.
It should also be named so that dot notation can be used, look at how it is done in https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GroupPower/Lemmas.html#Commute.cast_nat_mul_right for instance
I changed `theorem xyz` to `theorem Commute.xyz`.
Sorry, I had misunderstood your suggestion.  I've put the basic results in `Mathlib/Data/Nat/Cast/Commute.lean` and (I think) applied dot notation as you suggested.

```suggestion
    Commute (r+k) (pochEval s n)
```
and below, we use 4 spaces here so that there is visually difference between the statement and the start of the proof
Thank you.  I think it's fixed now.

By using dot-notation, these terms become so short that I wonder if they can just be inlined.
```suggestion
theorem Commute.mem_comm_translate (r s : R) (n : â„•) (h: Commute r s) : Commute r (s + n) := h.add_right (Nat.commute_cast r n)
```
I've inlined the proofs using dot-notation as you suggested.

```suggestion
theorem Commute.translate_comm_mem (r s : R) (n : â„•) (h : Commute r s) : Commute (r + n) s :=
  h.add_left (Nat.cast_commute n s)
```
Here too.

The multiplication occurs on the RHS of the statement. So the naming convention requires describing the LHS and then possibly `_eq_(descr_of_RHS)`. I've suggested a description of the LHS. Another option is to flip the statement and swap LHS and RHS.
```suggestion
theorem pochEval_add_right (r : R) (n : â„•) : âˆ€ (k : â„•),
```
I have followed your suggestion.

```suggestion
def multichoose [BinomialSemiring R] (r : R) (n : â„•) : R :=
  BinomialSemiring.multichoose r n
```

Could also be
```suggestion
def multichoose [BinomialSemiring R] : R â†’ â„• â†’ R :=
  BinomialSemiring.multichoose
```
here
I've chosen to follow @jcommelin's suggestion for now, but I don't actually know the relative merits of one over the other.

I think `r` should also be explicit in this lemma, just like `n`.
```suggestion
theorem factorial_mul_multichoose_eq_pochEval [BinomialSemiring R] (r : R) (n : â„•) :
```
I have followed your suggestion.

```suggestion
/-- `pochEval` directly evaluates the `n`-th Pochhammer polynomial at an element `r`. -/
```
I have followed your suggestion.

Would it make sense to simply define `pochEval` as the RHS of this lemma? Or is there a reason why the inductive definition is better for you?

Orthogonally, please merge `master` into your PR. In the mean time, `pochhammer` has been renamed to `ascPochhammer` and the descending version `descPochhammer` is about to enter `master` (or maybe it already happened).

I tried defining `pochEval` (or `ascPochEval`) using polynomial evaluation, but it the compiler complains unless I add `noncomputable`.  I thought it would be nice if the binomial coefficient functions (when eventually defined) were computable.  (Is there an advantage to having noncomputable defs?)
Okay, I've changed my mind, and have defined ascPochEval as you suggested.  The lets me eliminate the comparison theorem.
Sorry, I've changed my mind again to make a recursive definition, and changed the name to `Ring.ascFactorial`.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion section Semiring ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ascPochEval r (n + k) = ascPochEval r n * ascPochEval (r + n) k ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion --theorem inj_smul_factorial [BinomialSemiring R] (n : â„•) (r s : R) : ```

```suggestion
theorem commute_add_cast [NonAssocSemiring Î±] (r s : Î±) (n : â„•) (h : Commute r s) :
```
Can we make `NonAssocSemiring` a variable for this whole section actually?
I added the variable declaration for the section and removed it from the theorems.

```suggestion
binomial ring is a torsion-free commutative ring `R` such that for any `x âˆˆ R` and any `k âˆˆ â„•`, the
```
Done!

```suggestion
power by replacing subtraction with addition.  Thus, we consider a semiring `R` in which
```
Done!
Done!

```suggestion
theorem ascPochEval_zero (r : R) : ascPochEval r 0 = 1 := rfl
```
Done!

```suggestion
theorem ascPochEval_cast (n : â„•) : âˆ€ (k : â„•), ascPochEval (n : R) k = ascPochEval n k
```
Thank you, that sticks out.

```suggestion
theorem ascPochEval_eq_ascPochhammer_eval (r : R) :
  âˆ€ (k : â„•), ascPochEval r k = Polynomial.eval r (ascPochhammer R k)
```
Done!

```suggestion
theorem ascPochEval_eq_ascPochhammer_eval (r : R) :
  âˆ€ (k : â„•), ascPochEval r k = Polynomial.eval r (ascPochhammer R k)
```
Done!
Can we give this a more distinctive name, like `risingFactorial` or `ascendingFactorial` or something?
`Nat.ascFactorial` is similar, but is defined so that `Nat.ascFactorial n r = ascPochEval (n + 1) r`.  I didn't want to introduce any off-by-one confusion.

I'm still not sure about this, having two very similar ways of expressing the same thing is a recipe for additional work down the line. I'd really prefer it if there was a way to unify them. It seems to me that the definition of `ascFactorial` could be nonstandard, seeing as it doesn't match Wikipedia for one. It would be good to understand why it was defined in this way in mathlib in the first place and if possible change that rather than reimplementing it

I see there is even a big note at the top of that file saying * `Nat.ascFactorial`: The ascending factorial. Note that it runs from `n + 1` to `n + k`
  and *not* from `n` to `n + k - 1`. We might want to change that in the future. So I think that we should indeed look seriously into changing it

I changed it to `ascFactorial`.  In fact, I think it is worth changing the existing def of `Nat.ascFactorial` since it goes against essentially all of the existing literature, and also doesn't generalize well.

Sorry, I didn't reload the page before writing my comment, so our messages crossed.  I made a separate branch where `Nat.ascFactorial` is fixed (and I am nailing down the proofs that got broken), but now I am thinking perhaps `Nat.ascFactorial` should just be eliminated in favor of the general semiring `ascFactorial`.  Should I make a separate `RingTheory/ascFactorial.lean` file with few dependencies carrying just the definition and a few properties?
Following YaelDillies's suggestion, I've removed that section entirely.

```suggestion
  apply inj_smul_pos n.factorial r s (Nat.factorial_ne_zero n) h
```
also can this be `exact`? rather than apply?
I switched from tactic mode to a proof term.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion Commute r (s + n) := h.add_right (commute_cast r n) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion Commute (r + n) s := h.add_left (cast_commute n s) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion Commute (r + k) (s + n) := ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ascPochEval r (k.succ) = (ascPochEval r k) * (r + k) := rfl ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion | 0 => by rw [ascPochEval_zero, ascPochEval_zero, Nat.cast_one] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion âˆ€ (k : â„•), ascPochEval r k = Polynomial.eval r (ascPochhammer R k) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion Commute (r + k) (ascPochEval s n) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ascPochEval r (n + k) = ascPochEval r n * ascPochEval (r + n) k ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion n * r = n * s â†’ r = s := BinomialSemiring.inj_smul_pos n r s h ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion âˆ€ (k:â„•), ascPochEval r k = Polynomial.eval r (ascPochhammer R k) ```
This is just `ascPochhammer` as a bare function instead of a polynomial. Why not use `(ascPochhammer n k).eval`?
I had found it a bit cumbersome to work with the polynomials earlier, but that was when I was just starting Lean.  I'll try again.
Thank you for the suggestion.  This PR has become a lot cleaner.
I think it was better before.
Okay, I've restored that part.

Either this should be re-stated to use smul, or it should be renamed to use `_mul_`.

I think using `smul` would allow this definition to work for non-unital rings? Though I may be mistaken.

That is a very interesting observation!  Yes, we can extend to the non-unital case (and even the non-associative but power-associative case) if we redefine `multichoose` to take only strictly positive Nat inputs.  However, we would need a version of `Polynomial.eval` for polynomials with `Nat` (or just some `CommSemiring` with a `smul`) coefficients and vanishing constant terms.  Do you suppose that is best done in a separate PR?
I don't for a moment think you should make that generalization in this PR!

```suggestion
  nsmul_injective (n : â„•) : n â‰  0 â†’ Injective (n â€¢ Â· : R â†’ R)
```

```suggestion
  factorial_nsmul_multichoose : âˆ€ (r : R) (n : â„•),
```

```suggestion
class BinomialSemiring (R : Type u) extends Semiring R where
```
and everywhere else

```suggestion

* [J. Elliott, *Binomial rings, integer-valued polynomials, and Î»-rings*][elliott2006binomial]
```

Good style is to not specify universes unless you need to.
```suggestion
variable {R : Type*}
```

```suggestion
  nsmul_right_injective (n : â„•) (h : n â‰  0) : Injective (n â€¢ Â· : R â†’ R)
```
You'll have to `open Function` at the top.

The `_right` refers to the naming convention in #9095 (which is already mostly implemented for `mul`).

```suggestion
  /-- `ascFactorial r n` is divisible by n! (witnessed by `multichoose`). -/
```

```suggestion
  /-- The multichoose function witnesses the divisibility of `ascFactorial r n` by n! -/
```

What kinds of binomial semirings do you care about? WIth your current design, you will need to define `BinomialRing (R) extends Ring R`, `BinomialField R extends Field R`, etc... if you want to talk about rings/fields which are binomial.

An alternative solution is not extend but do a *mixin*:
```suggestion
class BinomialRing (R : Type u) [Semiring R] where
```
The advantage is that you need not introduce even more typeclasses later. The drawback is that you now have to write `[Semiring R] [BinomialRing R]` instead of `[BinomialSemiring R]`. (There's also performance concerns if your typeclass is used a lot, but that's irrelevant here)

I like this alternative.  I have been experimenting with a prop-valued mixin `Binomial R`, that can be defined for any `NonAssocSemiring R` with `Pow R â„•` but I need a new version of `Polynomial.eval` that uses SMul to use it.
That makes sense. You can always use the `Semiring` generality here for now while you refactor `Polynomial.eval`.

```suggestion
  factorial_nsmul_multichoose (r : R) (n : â„•) :
```

```suggestion
theorem factorial_nsmul_multichoose_eq_eval_ascPochhammer [BinomialSemiring R] (r : R) (n : â„•) :
```
just to make sure that people typing `evalpochhammer` in the docs will find your lemma.
That's a weird theorem to have since it's a trivial special case of `nsmul_injective`.

Do you think you will be able to completely supersede `Nat.multichoose` in the future? If so, do you mind leaving a TODO? Something like
```
## TODO

Replace `Nat.multichoose` with `Ring.multichoose`.
```
in the module doc.
This looks like an interesting idea.  I will need to try some experiments before coming to a conclusion.
Removing `Nat.multichoose` turned out to be pretty easy.

```suggestion
class IsBinomialRing (R : Type*) [Semiring R] : Prop where
```
will be less ambiguous
I liked your previous idea better, actually. It let us actually compute `multichoose`.

Given that you went back to the data-full approach,
```suggestion
class BinomialRing (R : Type*) [Semiring R] where
```

Can you explain what it *does*, rather than its relationship to other things? Your current docstring is interesting to have, but not as the primary description.
```suggestion
/-- ????

This is a generalization of the combinatorial multichoose function, given by choosing with
replacement. -/
```

```suggestion
instance Nat.instBinomialSemiring : BinomialRing â„• := by
```

This has two antipatterns:
* Not focussing goals: it's hard to tell where one field ends and the next begins
* Using `.mk` instead of `where` syntax.

It would be much better to write
```suggestion
instance Nat.instBinomialSemiring : BinomialRing â„• where
  nsmul_right_injective n hn r s hrs := Nat.eq_of_mul_eq_mul_left (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hn) hrs
  multichoose := Nat.multichoose
  factorial_nsmul_multichoose r n := by
    rw [Nat.multichoose_eq, smul_eq_mul, â† Nat.descFactorial_eq_factorial_mul_choose,
      ascPochhammer_nat_eq_descFactorial]
```
(untested)
Thank you, this is much better.

It seems that you haven't decided whether this should be called a `Ring` or a `Semiring`; can you rename either the instance or the typeclass (and perhaps add a brief note in a docstring somewhere about the disparity between what you formalized, what you named it, and what the literature does (since it sounds like the literate only talks about the ring case?)
I think I changed all the `Semiring` names to `Ring`.
Can you add a simp lemma that says `BinomialRing.multichoose = Ring.multichoose`? It sounds like we don't ever want the former to appear in a goal view.
Done!
The changes to this file are all cosmetic, right?
Yes, I had added some commutativity lemmas that turned out to be unnecessary.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define BinomialRing mixin

nodes.body: Hi, and thanks for your first PR! Could you please change the title of your PR to something more informative and following our [commit conventions](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/commit.html). For example `feat: define binomial rings` would be perfectly fine. Also, the "assigning" mechanism is made for reviewers and maintainers to assign themselves/someone else as responsible for the review process of that PR, so there's no point in assigning yourself to your own PR.
Thanks for your PR! I left a few comments.

Unfortunately @jjaassoonn accidentally merged his branch into yours in #3878 after [bors changed the base branch](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/bors.20changed.20base.20branch). You'd need to force push when you push the next time, or alternatively you may pull in the last commit and revert it.

Thanks!

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
